May it please yo
r
good L. the mater of Berghen
wherof I referred
e report to this letter, is thus in
effect. The
Governo
r
is married, as yo
r
L. kno-
weth, to
e eldest daughter of
Merode
, a gentleman
at
liveth in a neutral place, but is partially affected
to
e Enemies cause. I may well remember that long
sins I advertised yo
r
L. of certain letters intercepted
by whiche it might appeare, that
e Bishop of
Liege
had
promised
Parma
, to persuade w
t
Merode, (whose
aboade is commonly in
e Bishops diocese) to practise
w
t
his
daughter
, and w
t
e Governo
r
, to surrender the
towne in to
e Enemies handes. To bring this cunningly
to passe, both
e father and
e sonne, who is also for
e
Enemie, have bin busily imploied. For they have sent
at sundrie times, both letters and messages to
e Lady
Morgan (their hope to prevaile being most of all in
her) to dispose her affection to
e forsaid designe.
Especially of late, there was a messenger sent unto her,
who pretended somw
at
els, to be
e cause of his comming,
but finding for his purpose a fitte opportunitie, presen-
ted unto her a letter from her father: w
ch
being but of
credence, before he would declare
e effect of his mes-
sage, he fell downe upon his knees, and besought her
w
t
teares, to pardon w
at
soever he should utter unto her.
Whiche when she had promised, after he had used those
complementes, w
ch
he was willed from her father, whiche
were full of kinde protestations of his fatherly affection, he told her in
e end, That
e only thing, wherein her
father desired to be gratified by her, whereby she might
also make her self great, and doe a singular service
to God and
e contrey, was to induce her husband, to
resigne his government, to
e handes of
e
Kinge
. He
should be rewarded for it, w
t
suche honors and dignities, as
no man before had receaved
e like, for
e like kinde of
service.
fol.36v
This was presently discovered by
e Lady Morgan to
her husband. Nevertheles she intreated him in regard
of her worde, to be silent in
e mater towardes
e mes-
senger: w
ch
though he promised in respect of
e messen-
ger, and suffered him as then, to depart away quietly,
yet he made
e mater knowen to
e
Councel of state
.
Moreover this being done about two moneths
past,
e self same messanger is newly come againe, col-
louring his comming w
t
maters of contribution, but
bringing secretly w
t
him an other letter from her father.
Whereby
e Governo
r
perceaving, that he was sharply
bent to pursue his enterprise, caused an officer to sease
upon him, and sent him hither to
e Councel. And heere
examined he confesseth as muche as I have signified
before. The Councel of State, albeit they doe acknow-
ledge,
at they have bin alwaies in their warres, most
faithfully served by the Governo
r
, and will not seeme
in this action to have him in suspicion: yet conside-
ring his estate, w
ch
they thinke doth muche depend
upon
e benefit of
at Government, they feare very
muche lest in processe of time, the father will be able
to persuade w
t
his daughter, and
at she may finde
e
meanes to persuade her husband, or at lest to make
some ouverture, whereby
e towne in continuance, may
be wonne by surprise. For prevention wherof they
have had
e mater in debate, and have thought it very
requisit, if there could be any meanes, to provide the
Governo
r
of some other government (where they might
not stand in suche feare of
e forsaied practises) that
he should be then removed, w
t
e first opportunitie.
Alwaies understoode, that no alteration should be made,
but w
t
her
Ma
ties
allowance, and
e Governo
rs
contentac
o
n.
Not to troble yo
r
L. w
t
every circumstance, It was
supposed heere in Councell, that my
L. Burgh
by rea-
son of his youthe and valour, might affect some place
fol.37r
of continuall service against
e Enemie, and in that
behalf be desirous, to exchange his Garrison for
at of
Berghen. Wherupon they concluded, if they found
him willing therunto, to intreat her Hig
nes
by their
letters, to conferre
e
Brill
upon
e Governo
r
of Ber-
ghen. For there they are assured, there is no daunger
of surprise, and those counterfait occasions, of
e Ene-
mies often sending, will surcease of thesmselves. To
knowe
e sooner in that matter, wherunto
ei might trust,
they were earnest w
t
me, to use some conference w
t
my L. and to feele his disposition, for accepting
at offer.
Howbeit my L. for divers causes, but specially disliking
to hold any government from
e states, would not harken
to
e motion. Whiche being certified unto them, because
they knowe no other way,
at will be pleasing to
e Go-
verno
r
, they have thought it expedient, to proceede no
further in
e mater. Nevertheles they have determined
to execute
e party,
at undertooke
e forsaied message,
hoping thereby, that ether Merode and
e Enemie will
despaire of their purpose, and so give over those at-
temptes, or that at lest by that meanes, they shall finde
no more instruments, to deliver suche errandes.
This consultation of
e Councel hath bin warely helde,
w
t
out
e privitie of
e Governo
r
, or of any man els, that
is not of
e Councel, my L. Burgh excepted. Lest
notw
t
standing it should come in question hereafter, or
by those that knowe it but by bruites, be misreported
to her Ma
tie
I thought it my duty, to declare it wholy
as it was,
